p: Study participants were asked whether they felt more or less willing to vaccinate their children after reading the text. Three quarters of the study participants in both groups stated no change in their intention to vaccinate their children. After reading the neutral text, 23.1% ( n = 15) expressed a greater willingness to vaccinate. This compares to 21.6% ( n = 11) of the respondents in the group who read the humorous text [Ï‡ 2(2) = 0.848 ( p = 0.654)], indicating no difference in the effects of the two texts on vaccination attitudes.
